column4: umm... just out of curiosity, how do you change the partition number "on the fly"?
you can't.  hda is master, hdb is slave, and 1, 2, 3, and 4 are the four partitions.
so if the driver is primary master it is hda#, and if it is primary slave it is hdb#, and secondary master hdc#, secondary slave hdd#
I know.... what is why I was asking what you meant by:  "linux doesn't care, so you can make the hda1 disk hda2, the disk from the old box"

I meant that he can connect up the drive that is currently primary master as primary slave, and he'll still be able to boot the ubuntu partition, although now it will be hdb instead of hda.  you would have to modify /etc/fstab to compensate, and possibly /boot/grub/menu.lst.
the idea being to get around the fact that xp often refuses to boot unless it is the first partition on primary master
Don't need to explain ;)  been doin this for quite a while ;)....i just didn't understand what you meant
ok, even if you already know, probably there are other people listening who don't.
checked two 5.1 boxes, both have bzip2 in /usr/bin
more logical that they are in the same directory, so I can see why they would have moved one
as a NPU, you really can't harm anything anyway
